column1: Greymantle was a title borne by two famous characters in J.R.R. Tolkiens works. The first of these was Thingol
column2: the King of Doriath in the First Age. His Sindarin name Thingol (and its older Quenya equivalent
column3: Singollo) both meant Greycloak or Greymantle.

column1: The name reappeared in a quite different form in the Third Age
column2: when it was one of many acquired by the Wizard Gandalf on his journeys. It was said to come from a name given to him in the Westron or Westron. That original name was possibly Gandalf#Names
column3: translated into the language of the Rohirrim as Greyhame
column4: and so into modern English as Greymantle.
